Article.ArticleTitle: Impacts assessment of nitrification inhibitors on U.S. agricultural emissions of reactive nitrogen gases.

AbstractText: Fertilizer-intensive agriculture leads to emissions of reactive nitrogen (Nr), posing threats to climate via nitrous oxide (N<sub>2</sub>O) and to air quality and human health via nitric oxide (NO) and ammonia (NH<sub>3</sub>) that form ozone and particulate matter (PM) downwind. Adding nitrification inhibitors (NIs) to fertilizers can mitigate N<sub>2</sub>O and NO emissions but may stimulate NH<sub>3</sub> emissions. Quantifying the net effects of these trade-offs requires spatially resolving changes in emissions and associated impacts. We introduce an assessment framework to quantify such trade-off effects. It deploys an agroecosystem model with enhanced capabilities to predict emissions of Nr with or without the use of NIs, and a social cost of greenhouse gas to monetize the impacts of N<sub>2</sub>O on climate. The framework also incorporates reduced-complexity air quality and health models to monetize associated impacts of NO and NH<sub>3</sub> emissions on human health downwind via ozone and PM. Evaluation of our model against available field measurements showed that it captured the direction of emission changes but underestimated reductions in N<sub>2</sub>O and overestimated increases in NH<sub>3</sub> emissions. The model estimated that, averaged over applicable U.S. agricultural soils, NIs could reduce N<sub>2</sub>O and NO emissions by an average of 11% and 16%, respectively, while stimulating NH<sub>3</sub> emissions by 87%. Impacts are largest in regions with moderate soil temperatures and occur mostly within two to three months of N fertilizer and NI application. An alternative estimate of NI-induced emission changes was obtained by multiplying the baseline emissions from the agroecosystem model by the reported relative changes in Nr emissions suggested from a global meta-analysis: -44% for N<sub>2</sub>O, -24% for NO and +20% for NH<sub>3</sub>. Monetized assessments indicate that on an annual scale, NI-induced harms from increased NH<sub>3</sub> emissions outweigh (8.5-33.8 times) the benefits of reducing NO and N<sub>2</sub>O emissions in all agricultural regions, according to model-based estimates. Even under meta-analysis-based estimates, NI-induced damages exceed benefits by a factor of 1.1-4. Our study highlights the importance of considering multiple pollutants when assessing NIs, and underscores the need to mitigate NH<sub>3</sub> emissions. Further field studies are needed to evaluate the robustness of multi-pollutant assessments.
